Looking at the available documents, the Complaint is only partially visited (26% coverage), but the extraction from the first 10,000 tokens seems to have covered all the necessary information for the checklist items. The other documents are unvisited, but the checklist items are already fully covered based on the Complaint. 

The checklist definitions don't require any additional information from other documents. For example, Filing_Date is found in the header, Who_are_the_Parties is listed in the plaintiffs and defendants sections, Class_Action is confirmed in the case title and the Class Action Allegations section, and Type_of_Counsel is detailed in paragraph 51. 

I should check if there's any possibility of missing values. The Complaint document has all the necessary info, and since the extraction has 24 values across all keys, and the checklist items are all filled, there's no need to read more documents. The other documents like Docket, Orders, Settlement Agreements might have additional info, but the checklist items don't require them. For instance, Filing_Date is already set, and the other items are fully covered by the Complaint.

The system says to stop when all keys are filled or set to Not Applicable. Here, all keys have values, so the next step is to stop. The recent action was an append_checklist that successfully added all the values, so no further actions are needed. I should use the stop decision with the reason that all checklist items are fully extracted.
